p: We note that the use of ethanol from sugarcane as a gas substitute leads to a very important reduction in greenhouse gases emissions, which can reach up to 85% [ 95, 96]. This is mostly due to the fact that they replace fossil fuels [ 97], and sequester carbon through the growth of the feedstock [ 98, 99], especially when pastures are converted to sugarcane fields and managed without fire [ 95]. The use of ethanol from sugarcane, produced in landscapes with a large amount of connected forest cover, could ameliorate disease risk, since it would increase diversity community, diminishing reservoir rodent abundance, and would contribute to climate mitigation.
